"I want to see a show of hands who here feels like their relationship with their dad defines their feminism in some way?Â 

Mine does, but only in this sense that my dad is and always has been a supportive person to me. I truly think that only I set my direction for my feminism, and always have, regardless of my parents' opinions.

But I suppose, when the first man you ever meet, turns out to be someone who treats women like whole people, you can't help but be convinced of the same! And my mum is a very forthright independent woman, so that helps.Â 

.
.
#feminism #womensempowerment #womensrights #mumlife #daddysgirl"

label: general
post_content:
"Which parts of this resonate with your experience of motherhood? I always want my page to be a safe space for mothers to be able to express their true feelings and experiences, whether those be positive, negative, or anywhere in between.

Motherhood is a politicised social role which props up the entire economy; meanwhile mothers undertake this essential work largely without any kind of remuneration. 

And they are expected to be grateful for the opportunity to do 24/7 psychologically and physically devastating work for free and in many ways unsupported.

As you know, I am childfree very much by choice. A huge driver of this choice is my transparent and honest appreciation of what actually goes into raising a child. It's because I AM empowered to see what motherhood in a patriarchy is like, that I am able to know I don't want it. 

Because of the brave and vulnerable truth-telling of mothers, now and throughout history, I have the information women so desperately need. 

So mothers, please continue telling your truth, so that we can all be empowered to fight for motherhood to be better respected and supported.

#Motherhood #MomLife #MumLife #MomProblems #Housework #Childcare #Perinatal #PayGap"

"Day 4 // @sommertothill is a Brisbane-based feminist writer and presenter with a background in TV, writing, and radio, known for her work on gender equality and her notable career moments, including MC-ing Clementine Fordâ€™s book launch and inspiring an entire Andrew Bolt tantrum devoted to one of Sommerâ€™s feminist op-eds. 

Family and domestic violence is deeply rooted in power imbalances, with women being disproportionately affected. 
This violence means itâ€™s not just about individuals losing controlâ€”itâ€™s about systemic issues that uphold male dominance. In Australia, men are responsible for the vast majority of violence against women, and this isnâ€™t an isolated or random occurrence. Itâ€™s a pattern fueled by societal expectations, gender roles, and the normalisation of violence as a tool of control. Acknowledging this gendered element is essential to understanding the true nature of family and domestic violence. 

#16daysofactivism #16daysofactivismagainstgenderbasedviolence #auspol"

post_content:
"This post was really controversial on Threads but I struggle to see why. Most people, despite their values and despite their best self-belief, wouldn't actually intervene in an abuse scenario - espeically a physical one. If they did, many fewer women would be harmed, wouldn't they? 

It's like how having a weapon in your home actually increases the likelihood that *you* will be harmed. Most of us are not equipped with the skills to physically defend ourselves or others, and we can make the situation much worse. 

This post presents ways to try to meaningfully lead an abuse victim to a safer outcome. I don't know what's so hard to compute about that, hey. 

Maybe my Threads algorithm is the problem. I feel like you guys get it!"

label: general
post_content:
"Diane â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹ğŸŒˆ

When Diane had her initial work up, she was relatively unremarkable apart from her hydration status & some gas distention. They couldnâ€™t pass a tube. It just kept going into the trachea & she wouldnâ€™t swallow it. I went ahead & took her home, ran some IV fluids & continued to monitor her as they donâ€™t offer 24/7 monitoring. 

She stayed comfortable until the end of her banamine dose. I noticed her looking at the ground & her heart rate was around 55, so I gave her a round of sedation. She blew through it in less than 20 minutes & her gums had changed within that time frame. I immediately unhooked the line & loaded herâ€¦ 

I was sure she would be down by the time we got there, but she was standing, her HR was now 100+. They got her in & started diagnostics. They couldnâ€™t get a tube passed (why her nose was bleeding) & her stomach was about to rupture. They scoped her to see why the tube wouldnâ€™t pass & she just wouldnâ€™t swallow itâ€¦ They got a tiny tube & guided it with a scope to get it to the stomach. They pulled a ton of reflux off her stomach which relieved a lot of the pain.

Her abdominal lactate was bad, but the color was good, so the initial suspicion was that it was an enteritis or ileal impaction. She declined over the next 8 hours. She had continual reflux, they werenâ€™t getting ahead of her hydration & her pain was increasing. They reultrasounded her & saw a pretty definitive ileocecal intussusception. Basically the intestine telescopes itself. The only fix is surgery & she was not a candidate. 

When we got into the recovery box to euthanize her - she got really nervous. Started head ticking & sitting back on her hind legs heavier. I asked them if we could do it outside in the grass. They donâ€™t like to do the draft without the support wall, but I told them I was aware that she could fall really hard & it not be pretty. Initially they pushed not to, but I just did not want her to leave scared. We walked her outside & her ears immediately perked up. She stood calm in the grass & laid down beautifully. She went easy. 

Itâ€™s been a hard 24 hours. Please consider a final gift to Diane for her years of abuse & service she didnâ€™t deserve ğŸ’”"

label: general
post_content:
"Our sweet, sweet baby ğŸ¥¹

After her first surgery, her respiratory effort became increased & after ultrasound & radiographs - it was confirmed to be pneumonia. Her mom tested positive for EHV1 m, however the foalâ€™s test came back negative. Sheâ€™s already on systemic antibiotics for her leg, but theyâ€™ve added nebulization which is helping a lot so far. 

The pneumonia adds a lot of complications to the orthopedic side of things. Itâ€™s very risky to use anesthesia on animals with compromised lungs like this - especially a foal. Thankfully she is such a good baby - they were able to lavage the joint, implant new antibiotics beads, inject an antibiotic & rebandage with just a local block. Sheâ€™s sore, but using the leg more & more which is the best we can hope for so far ğŸ™ğŸ½

She unfortunately scratched her cornea somehow while in hospitalâ€¦ She wasnâ€™t responding to the initial schedule of med applications, so they had to increase this to applying every 2 hours. This adds a fair bit of cost to the bill, however we are hoping in a few days they can go back down. Both mom & baby also got a lice bath â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹ 

With the eye complication - we could use all the help we can get with their climbing bill ğŸ¥ The mom is such a kind Jenny & the little one - well sheâ€™s just the best. I mean just look at her! A true angel baby. ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜

label: general
post_content:
"What is rescue?
For me - itâ€™s this. Giving them the chance they always should have had. 
Advocating for them when most wouldnâ€™t. Stepping up when most step away. Clinging onto hope and optimism despite what the world and humanity has shown us. Actively seeking the good, the glimmers, the shred of a miracle that might be there if you just try. 
That is why I love the rescue community so much. Because you all see it too. You see that they are worthy of a chance and rally to give it to them.

We still have a LONG road ahead of us for the three rescued last weekend. 
Christina has done an excellent job posting updates on treatment plans, progress and prognosis of mama, baby donkey and the grey mare that has cancer. 

Collectively, between the three, their hospitalizations will be a lot. We knew it would be. But whenever I get overwhelmed and think, â€œthere is just no way. How are we going to pull this off?â€
I break it down
It may seem like a lot for ONE person but we arenâ€™t ONE person. We are a community. A community of hundreds of thousands of people who care.

When you start to break it down, it is really just

â¡ï¸3,000 people donating 5
OR
â¡ï¸1,5000 people to donate 10
OR
â¡ï¸750 people donating 20
OR
â¡ï¸300 people donating 50

Thereâ€™s power in community. Thereâ€™s power in numbers. There is over a BILLION people that log onto Instagram every day and all we need it 3,000 of you to say â€œyes. I can help you.â€ Itâ€™s possible. Itâ€™s doable. Itâ€™s worth it. 

Rescue is SO MUCH MORE than the initial pull to safety. The real rescue comes AFTER - to provide care and ALL of the chances they deserve.

label: general
post_content:
"We said goodbye to sweet Julep this morning â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹ğŸŒˆ

Unlike most of the others, this was a goodbye we knew was coming. Julep was a ex racehorse who was used as a broodmare in Kentucky for most of her life. She landed here with us to live out her last days. She was blind in her right eye & was your typical antsy thoroughbred. She was also the one mare ALL the boys fought over lol. 

The last 6 months Julep had been struggling with chronic laminitis. We got ahead of it for a while with custom orthopedic shoes, but this last cycle she abscessed & we had to pull her shoes to soak & bandage her hooves. With her age & the chronicity of this, we decided this was an ongoing battle she didnâ€™t need to fight. 

She spent longer hours lying down in the pasture the past week & we knew was ready. I didnâ€™t want to trailer her, so a vet came out to euthanize her. We laid her to rest in the trailer, so my dad could bury her at our other property next to her BFF, Mystic. 

She laid down gently & went very, very easy. Her body was tired. She lived a loved 5+ years with us. Rest easy sweet JuJu â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹ğŸŒˆğŸ•Šï¸

Please consider small donation towards Julepâ€™s final gift. It wasnâ€™t terribly expensive since my dad is able to bury her. Weâ€™ve had so much the last two weeks & any help with this vet bill & our other vet bills is so appreciated ğŸ™ğŸ½ğŸ’”

label: general
post_content:
"Cue â€œMagical Princess Unicornâ€ ğŸ¦„ğŸ°ğŸ‘‘

This beautiful girl is so full of life! She still has a long way to go in her physical healing. Her surgery to remove the melanoma around her vulva & anus is scheduled for June 17th. They could barely get more than a few fingers in to rectally palpate her. If the tumors arenâ€™t removed - eventually, as they grow larger, she wonâ€™t be able to pass manure. It will be done in two parts to reduce the amount of trauma at once to the delicate area & maximize success. They will also remove the rather large third eye lid tumor on her left eye while she is there. 

Once we tackle these & she has time to heal - we can treat her lips with a chemo injection. They are HUGE, but itâ€™s a really hard to surgically remove these due to the skin, tension, constant motion, etc. so the chemo route is preferred. 

The care she needs isnâ€™t going to be cheap. We have had huge medical expenses this month with many more to come. This mare, the donkeys & Munchieâ€™s all started as something small & very manageable/treatable. They are now huge issues because their previous humans failed them so miserably. They all deserve the care they need, they all want to live & despite their pain & challenges - they live with such radiant & joyous spirits. 

These vet bills are on top of our primary vet bills, feed, hay, farrier, daily supplies, medicine, etc. Deworming alone was $1,000 this month. Itâ€™s a lot & we really need support for these beautiful animals if you are able to donate or join our Patreon as a monthly donor. The smallest amount for everyone adds up ğŸ’•

I hope you can see the impact your donations make not only physically, but emotional as well. I even am shocked at their transformations sometimes. Like how was this the nervous mare at auction a few weeks ago?! ğŸ¦„

label: general
post_content:
"Unpopular opinion - mares are so much easier than geldings. 

No one will ever convince me that mares are just moody or geldings are so much quieter. Mares are like women and geldings are like men lol. The geldings fight & get possessive of the girls constantly. They are needy, get so attached, fight each other, cause drama. Then thereâ€™s our mares. They all get along with each other, any initial issues are worked out & then never an issue again, they share food without fights, they donâ€™t start trouble or mischief. They are so intelligent, so willing & always put 110% in. They wonâ€™t however just submit, feel safe or be easy going if they donâ€™t feel Iike their feelings are being heard or acknowledged. 

Ignoring mares feelings and saying â€œitâ€™s just because theyâ€™re just a mareâ€ is reactive abuse. You do something that bothers them, they probably warned you 500x & you still ignore it, finally they lash out & then they are the â€œvillainâ€. This is true for both geldings & mares, but mares, atleast in my opinion, are more emotional & intelligent. They have to be to be mothers & raise their foals. The boysâ€¦ well they are a little more â€œsimple mindedâ€ lol. 

Maybe Iâ€™m the 1% that thinks this, but with our mixed herds in large pastures - the girls are so easy. The geldings... well Frodo explains the love hate with them in this video ğŸ¤£"

"Sebastian ğŸ¦€

He was one of the most resentful & defensive orphans we have ever taken on. He missed kicking me in the head when I was just in his paddock scooping manure by about 2 inches as a yearlingâ€¦ It took over a year of asking nothing, positive reactions & being present to get here. When horses are really combative (kick, bite, etc.) itâ€™s normal to think they need to be lunged, learn manners, etc. when in reality they just feel betrayed. I now try to avoid conflict all together with horses like this & make sure they know I see their feelings & donâ€™t push them past their threshold. Some horses quickly come around. Others, like Sebastian, take longer, but trust is built - not just compliance â¤ï¸

We met our $6 Saturday goal! Thank you so much everyone ğŸ™ğŸ½â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹ Itâ€™s been a lot lately & your support means a lot - both to me & the horses ğŸ«‚"

Healing physical wounds in rescue is crucial, but healing the emotional wounds is equally as important. You can be physically healthy while locked in a mental prison. Friendship, safety & connection bring out the best in everyone - including animals. 

Baby cow (who clearly still needs a name lol) is finally coming around from his emotional wounds & trauma. When they first wake up to a â€œdead/freezeâ€ internalized state - they are finally able to start seeing the world around them. label: general
post_content:
"Today is the day she gets her chance. 

She was dumped at a sale barn, with cancerous lesions in her mouth, anus and vulva, as well as several other growths on various areas of her body. They put a bit in her cancerous mouth and rode her through an auction ring - never disclosing her cancer to the bidders.

We knew though. We assessed her prior to the sale and knew if we didnâ€™t intervene - she would be in danger of either being dumped right back in the circuit - passed around getting sicker and sicker - or end up in the wrong hands of someone not equipped or willing to provide treatment and sanctuary. To bridle her, saddle her, ride her with cancer anyways. Itâ€™s exactly why we rescued her. She deserves unconditional love, treatment and rest. 

To add more heartache, when assessed by the vet - they determined she had milk. Meaning she recently had a baby pulled off her. Not only did they leave her cancer untreated - she grew and BIRTHED a foal with a cancerous body and cancerous genitals. The pain of that. I cannot imagine.

It makes me so angry. So sad. So upset for her. 

But we are here now - rallying to do right by her. 

If 1,000 people donate 5 dollars - we will finish raising the cost of her surgeries, 4 weeks of hospitalization she will need as well as the chemo injections for her mouth and cover the cost of getting her out of that hell hole. 

Rescue is SO MUCH MORE than the initial pull to safety. The real rescue comes AFTER - to provide care and ALL of the chances they deserve. 

Christina from Freedom Reins has lovingly taken this beautiful girl in to both provide treatment and sanctuary her for the rest of her life. No more riding, no more babies, no more expectations. Just rest. Just comfort. Just a chance. 

For continued updates, please follow @freedomreins on Instagram."

label: general
post_content:
"Regina & Sarah â¤ï¸ 

An ex Amish Belgian & an orphaned saddlebred baby. Draft mares are the of epitome strength & resilience yet they never lose their willingness to be vulnerable & empathetic. 

We always let our horses decide who they are friends with & feel safe with them when we bring them in for feedings - we keep their friend groups together. I donâ€™t quite understand it yet, but every orphan foal we have rescued has had an immediate connection with one of the draft mares (Moosette, Diane, Regina, Madonna). So much so that many try nursing for weeks if not monthsâ€¦

Whatâ€™s really profound is every draft mare has without hesitation has taken them in & protected them as their own. Bambi & Flower were like little ducklings following Moosette before she had Max. Sarah hasnâ€™t left Reginaâ€™s side since we rescued Regina almost 18 months ago & Frodo immediately saw Diane as her momâ€¦ ğŸ¥² 

Nala is the exception & has taken in Sebastian & Diamond. Diamond & Sebastian had to stay in a small paddock with some stall rest due to both physical development issues & mental trauma. They ended up bonded heavily to each other during that initial year & now they are mostly with Nala. Regina & Moosette babysit them time to time though lol. 

Our other mares (non draft) are wonderful. They all protect the babies & keep the bully geldings on the outskirts away from them, but they havenâ€™t taken on that true â€œmotherâ€ role. We might get a horse that changes this pattern in our rescues, but so far it hold tried & true. Itâ€™s beautiful to witness because the love between the orphan foals & the draft mares is true & unconditional - itâ€™s not based on breed, looks, what they can benefit from or take. Itâ€™s something we all as humans can learn from & be inspired by â¤ï¸

#horses #horsesofinstagram #horserescue #equestrian"

label: general
post_content: "Rescue isnâ€™t easy. The long hours, the financial cost, the cumulative grief, the never ending demand for you to do more, take in more, be there for more because so many others simply wonâ€™t or arenâ€™t willing to do the right thing. Itâ€™s overwhelming, stressful & not something I would wish on anyone, but if we donâ€™t who will? These horses are worthy of kindness, care & unconditional love. â¤ï¸"

"2020 â¡ï¸ 2024

Nala is one of the sweetest horses Iâ€™ve ever been around. Sheâ€™s safe, sheâ€™s kind & sheâ€™s so easy going. I moved her & her orphan baby Diamond together. I worried about Diamond on so much acreage (I think just from the PTSD of losing her twin Sarah), but Nala lived on our ranch for 3 years. Sheâ€™s a veteran, so I know Diamond is safe with her ğŸ©·

Once I get everyone settled & I get a few fundraisers for vetting & hay out of the way - we will focus on fundraising for new property. Iâ€™m so excited to start looking for a permanent home for Freedom Reins! 

Please consider joining our Patreon (patreon.com/freedomreins) for as little as $5/month! post_content:
"ğŸŒ¾ $6 SATURDAY FOR ALFALFA ğŸŒ¾

This week I am working on getting the hay feeders & a few loads of alfalfa to the property near Austin. This is where roughly 2/3 of the horses are right now â¤ï¸

Many of the horses do not venture from the neighbors fence line & the main pond meaning they arenâ€™t grazing or touching 75% of the property. They are being home bodies since the move was a big change for all of them which is understandable. As they get comfortable Iâ€™m sure they will venture out to explore - however, I need to give them access to hay 24/7 while they acclimate & while we mow/get the grass in better shape. 

We have a load of alfalfa being delivered tomorrow afternoon. Itâ€™ll be 70 - $30 3 string bales, so our fundraiser goal is $2100! â¤ï¸

I donâ€™t want to put round bales out at the Austin property right now. Iâ€™m too scared to risk the chance of an ileal impaction & stomach ruptureâ€¦ None of the horses there have had an ileal impaction previously, however itâ€™s not a risk Iâ€™m willing to take right now given I donâ€™t live onsite with them & they can rupture in a matter of hours. 

Please consider a $6 donation today so these sweet babies can keep eating like the little piggies they are! ğŸŒ¾ğŸ· We only need 350 $6 donors to meet our goal! ğŸ™ğŸ½

label: general
post_content:
"Loss doesnâ€™t make you stronger. Iâ€™m not stronger from back to back losses weâ€™ve had this year. Iâ€™m not stronger watching their last breaths. If anything I feel weaker with each loss - not stronger. What loss does do is it changes you. Iâ€™m not the same person I was a year ago or even 6 months ago. In some ways for the better - in others for the worse. 

For better - Iâ€™ve learned to be grateful for loss & what I wished wouldnâ€™t have happened, that every day is a gift & nothing - absolutely nothing - matters in the end except love. 

For worse - The anticipation that tragedy is around the corner when things are good, cynicism from the never ending cruelty & narcissism in the world (especially around animals) & learning to dissociate long term as a survival mechanism to avoid the reality b/c life doesnâ€™t stop for anyoneâ€™s grief. 

To love is to grieve & to have is to lose.

#rescue #grief #loss #equestrian #farmanimals #horses #horsesofinstagram"

She also had intermittent rectal prolapse - likely due to parasites, so they will run a fecal to check. Itâ€™s really important that Floraâ€™s lungs are not compromised before she goes to surgery, so they will do chest radiographs, a respiratory panel, bloodwork & an ultrasound on Monday â¤ï¸

label: general
post_content:
"My sweet Spike ğŸ•Šï¸ğŸŒˆğŸ’”

Spike was surrendered last year with Gus by an elderly man who had onset of dementia. He was used as a cow horse before retiring about 4 years ago. He was a saint & the horse I trusted most out of all the rescues even though our time together was short.

He was 27 years old & thankfully never had to endure an auction, kill pen or the slaughter pipeline. While no necropsy was done - Spike appears to have passed from sudden cardiovascular death. He spent the entire day hanging out with us on Sunday & he was his bright, happy self. Monday he was gone. He had no struggle marks, no sweat marks even on his down side & he was still clean/groomed. 

From what I could see he was walking down the hill & collapsed. He kicked three times with his left hind & was gone. He had a cut on his rump, but I put a glove on & thoroughly checked it. Iâ€™m not sure where he got it, but it was superficial & did not appear related in any way. He lived an easy leisure life here, so I canâ€™t say I noticed any clear symptoms of heart related issues such as exercise intolerance. He was able to just be a happy old man & go at his own pace like he deserved. 

Of course I have a million what ifâ€™s running through my head & itâ€™s hard not having that clear cut diagnostic of what caused this... It makes me think of all the 1% of possible causes for sudden death that could affect more than just him. Spike was one of my favorite horses & Iâ€™m devastated. I cherished having him around, but I donâ€™t have time to grieve this week. I wanted to cry yesterday, but I didnâ€™t. Compartmentalizing so heavily takes its toll long term, but sadly it is needed in rescue. I have to focus on Flora, her surgery & getting her fundraiser done before Thursday."

post_content:
"â€œeverytime i lose someone new
it isnâ€™t just one loss
it is every loss iâ€™ve ever felt.
~grief is cumulative.â€ - Whitney Hanson

Thank you everyone, my fellow rescuers, followers & friends for the condolences, kind messages & love. This community is a beautiful one ğŸ«‚ Loss is always hard. Losing a baby is especially devastating. Losing two babiesâ€¦ leaves you shattered. This year has been filled with so much loss, many being traumatic emergencies, & Iâ€™d be lying if I said it hasnâ€™t taken its toll. 

I took the last week off social media to just be more present with the horses & cows. I will gradually get back to full capacity, but hereâ€™s a photo dump from the week with some of the rescues ğŸŒˆğŸ•Šï¸"

I know I have been less active & havenâ€™t gotten to messages yet, but I hope in this video you are able to see how even after a huge move, change & uprooting a few months ago - they feel & know they are safe & loved. post_content:
"We need help & donations. Only a handful of people have stepped up for OptiMooseâ€™s emergency & we havenâ€™t even got to hay, farrier or Blue, Gus & the otherâ€™s vetting. I canâ€™t go to auction every month & fundraise/take new animals in with caring for so many special needs/hospice cases we have here.

Saving animals from auction is needed - most of these are auction saves, but a lot of them need soft landings. Please remember to support smaller sanctuaries because itâ€™s getting harder & harder for us. Blueâ€™s vet bill is around $3,500. If he were at auction next weekend the money would get raised, but since heâ€™s in a sanctuary it doesnâ€™t get much attention. Horse rescue has so many different working parts. Itâ€™s not just auction. Itâ€™s local, its owner surrenders, its sanctuary, its legislature. Itâ€™s not just auction. It is no secret that auction is the easiest way to raise funding. Saving new lives is wonderful, but we have to stay committed to the lives already saved right? I only say this so awareness can be raised for rescues that donâ€™t attend auction monthly b/c our ability to keep up continues to get harder.

#horses #animalrescue #animals"

My beautiful client @kirathelight shared: 

ğŸ‘‰Due to my warm skin tone, I was always told that I have a warm undertone. 

I was trying warm makeup colors on me, like warm contouring, blush, and lipsticks in corals and oranges, and it always felt wrong. âŒ

I felt overly sick, washed out, and yellow. ğŸ¥¹

At one point, I intuitively started leaning towards cool colors, and it felt much better. 

When I came to Julia, she reconfirmed that I have a cool undertone. âœ”ï¸

I canâ€™t be happier to know that I was right and that warm colors are not the best choice for me. âœ¨

â€”
ğŸ‘‰So, my darlings, even with a warm skin tone, you can still have a cool undertone.

post_content:
"Iâ€™ve been dealing with post-inflammatory erythema (p.i.e) for over a year and wasted my money on countless products that did nothing for my skin. If youâ€™ve also been suffering with skin issues and havenâ€™t seen any improvements, I encourage you to visit a professional skin specialist. My experience with Anya has been incredibly insightful and helped me reconnect with my body and spirit. Skin health can be treated externally, but it starts from within ğŸ¤

The team at @royalyorkspa was kind enough to offer you all a discount with my promo code KIRA20 to save 20% off on treatments, products, memberships and gift cards!

The Customâ€” Fusion Facial:

The process began with a calming oil-based cleanser to prepare my skin for actives, followed by a water-based toner and gel exfoliant to protect and prep my barrier. Anya then applied a creamy, anti-inflammatory base enriched with retinol, glycolic, salicylic acid, and hyaluronic acid, followed by a soothing emulsion and facial steamer to address brightness and texture.

She even noticed my eyes looked offâ€”a result of being sick for a monthâ€”and focused on healing them as well. This attention to detail was so thoughtful!

Extractions came next, which were a little painful but totally worth it for clearing clogged pores, blackheads, and impurities. Anya used a high-frequency wand afterward to disinfect and promote healing, and she convinced me to invest in my own device for at-home care.

The highlight of the session was her relaxing scalp and lymphatic drainage massage with her custom jojoba-based cream infused with vitamin C, retinol, and salicylic actives. This melted away my tension and even radiated calm energy to my daughter, who was with me.

To finish, Anya used an ultrasonic cold therapy device to lock in moisture and gave me the most beautiful glow."

"Iâ€™ve been connecting to the lower notes lately. 
When I first discovered binaural beats a decade ago, fear prevented me from exploring these deeper tones. It took a lot of time and courage to decondition my brain and allow these grounding sounds to guide me through this path of healing. Positivity and light is shiny and beautiful, but there is also so much beauty and love in darkness. 
The moon is a strong example ğŸŒ’

Trauma and repressed emotions can be stored within our bodiesâ€”we face them especially during triggering moments. 
One day you could be bursting with love and enthusiasm, and the next youâ€™re questioning where it all went. Healing is like a spiral ğŸŒ€ cycle after cycle, we expand and grow with time. Balancing these polarities of life has been my saving grace ğŸ–¤ğŸ¤

This sound bath was created with the intention of fearlessly sharing our truths. The crystal and Tibetan bowls used were in the note G, which represents our throat chakra (clarity, resonance and creativity).
This song is love letter to those who have been doubting their skills and abilities. To those who are afraid to take that leap of faith. 
You are safe, and I hope these frequencies could be a gentle reminder âœ¨

post_content:
"The story behind my collaboration with Atoms for a sneaker: I think my favorite video Iâ€™ve ever made was when I got to interview Kobe Bryant (during his farewell tour season, in the basement of the Staples Center). I was obviously pretty awestruck, (it was my first interview ever) but I also came away from that super impressed with his approach to creating his own sneakers. He had an incredible amount of input into all of the details of his own signature shoe, and it showed. Turns out thatâ€™s pretty rare for a signature shoe athlete.

Fast forward a few years, and when Atoms approached me with their vision for a completely new sneaker, I was immediately intrigued. Now I wonâ€™t name names, but Iâ€™d actually gotten that pitch before, but it turned out to essentially be a chance to slap my name on something that was almost finishedâ€¦ not interested in that. But Atoms was completely game to start from scratch and create something completely newâ€¦ I couldnâ€™t say yes fast enough.

This was in 2020, and I was straight off to the drawing board, firing ideas at Atoms designers and experts, and figuring out what could work, what couldnâ€™t, what would cost more, what would cost less, etc. It quickly grew into a deep collaboration between myself and the Atoms team. We shared a passion for design and innovation, and we knew that we could create something truly unique together.

So if you havenâ€™t already, I encourage you to check out the result of the MKBHD x Atoms collaboration. It represents my best ideas as a product enthusiast, and a sneakerhead for a comfortable, versatile, daily wear shoe. It's only available for a limited time, and it's a chance to own something truly special. Thanks for your support, guys, and as always, stay tuned for more!

#WearYourKicks"

post_content:
"I love electric cars, but as I've said on the Auto Focus channel there are certain TYPES of vehicles that with today's tech are BEST when made electric. Take a luxury sedan - what do you want from the best one? It better be super smooth, comfortable, quiet (and probably expensive). A new electric version? Literally the smoothest, quietest, most spacious version ever. (also probably expensive). Total win across the board. 

But sports cars are not one of those things. Yet. The power is there, duh, but there's also a ton of weight that comes with it. And the best sports car across the board rivers best when it's lighter, nimble and reliable. The gap is closing (and hybrids are getting VERY good) out the apex sports car is still not fully electric. 

Honestly I was nervous to get it after watching basically every review on the internet proclaiming this to be the "best car ever created" and "too good" but the professionals were on to something. I'm not ready to say it's the best car ever made, but most of its traits are already top 5% of any car I've ever experienced: Handling, steering feel, balance, physical switches, interior build quality, speakers, acceleration (ok it's 8/10ths as quick as PLAID)

The tech is actually kinda bad compared to new EVs. The backup camera is weak, there's no phone key, the app does almost nothing, no dashcam, wireless CarPlay/Android Auto are welcome but also honestly still not very good. I don't even think that's a hot take.

I've compared smartphones to the Porsche 911's incremental improvement model for years. When the category is young, we call it lazy. When the category is mature, we call it refinement. And I'm only 700 miles in, but damn this car is REFINED as hell.

So this is the new daily ğŸ¤“ It's no Carrera GT (â™¥ï¸ @dougdemuro) but it's MY Turbo S and i love this thing

For the Porsche nerds
2024 992 Turbo S
Jet black metallic + Stealth PPF
PASM, PCCB, Sports Aero, Front axle lift, glass roof
Chalk stitching
Carbon mirror caps, door trim, GT steering wheel
Wheels powder coated, brakes painted and glossy hood stripe by @autopolishingcenter

Is there a 992.2 hybrid refresh coming? Yes. Worth upgrading? I guess we'll see ğŸ˜ˆ"

post_content:
"The most dangerous thing about the Cybertruck isn't the pointy corners. It isn't the blind spots or the blinding glare off the stainless steel in the sun or the way the front trunk closes. No. The most dangerous thing about the Cybertruck is how it makes everyone else around you on the road behave ğŸ˜­

I've seen people accelerate and cut people off to get a video of the truck on their phone WHILE driving. I've seen people stop in the middle of a one way street to take a picture of it parked. I've seen people wobble around in their lane and damn near leave the road trying to get their phone out of their pocket as it passes by. I pulled into an intersection once and two kids in bikes straight up biked into the middle of the intersection to get a nice snap of it. I have hundreds of sentry mode clips of more - people looking inside, stopping in their tracks - probably 75% in awe and 25% in disgust lol.

The Cybertruck is - at least right now - a celebrity. No idea how long this will be true or how long until they're mass produced and everywhere in the road and this all wears off. But what I can tell you today is if you don't like attention... if you don't want a conversation EVERY time you park... if you don't want EVERYTHING you do on the road recorded... don't get a Cybertruck ğŸ˜…"

post_content:
"Air Abrasion teeth ğŸ¦· whitening 

Air abrasion is a technique that uses a stream of tiny aluminum oxide particles to remove surface stains and plaque from teeth, but it is not typically used for whitening purposes. Instead, it is more commonly employed for minimal cavity preparations, cleaning, or removing old fillings.

For teeth whitening, traditional methods like hydrogen peroxide-based bleaching treatments, laser whitening, or over-the-counter whitening strips are more effective in lightening the color of the teeth. Air abrasion can help improve the overall cleanliness and smoothness of teeth, but it doesnâ€™t have the same bleaching effect as these whitening treatments.

If youâ€™re considering teeth whitening, it might be useful to consult a dentist to determine the best approach based on your specific needs."

The force applied can lead to chipped, cracked, or even broken teeth, along with potential damage to the surrounding bone or gums. Dental injuries like this often require costly and painful repairs, including crowns, root canals, or even extractions.\n\nItâ€™s always important to protect your teeth by avoiding hard or non-food objects, especially something as solid as a hammer."

post_content:
"Elastics in orthodontics are small rubber bands that are commonly used in braces to help move teeth into their correct positions. They apply consistent force on the teeth to adjust the bite and alignment. The elastics are typically attached to hooks on the brackets and are stretched across either the top and bottom teeth or within the same arch.

There are several types of elastics based on their function:

	1.	Class I Elastics: Used within the same dental arch to close spaces between teeth.
	2.	Class II Elastics: Attached from the upper canine to the lower molar, helping to correct overbites.
	3.	Class III Elastics: Attached from the lower canine to the upper molar, used to fix underbites.
	4.	Crossbite Elastics: Correct crossbites by aligning upper and lower teeth laterally.
	5.	Vertical Elastics: Help close the bite by bringing the teeth together vertically.

Elastics need to be worn consistently as prescribed to ensure treatment progresses as planned."

"A Temporary Anchorage Device (TAD) is a small titanium screw used in orthodontics to provide a stable point of anchorage for moving teeth. Itâ€™s temporarily fixed in the bone and can be removed once the desired tooth movement is achieved.

TADs are used to:

	â€¢	Improve the precision and efficiency of certain tooth movements.
	â€¢	Reduce the need for more traditional anchorage devices like headgear.
	â€¢	Enhance treatment outcomes, especially in complex cases like closing spaces or correcting overbites.

Insertion of a TAD is minimally invasive, typically done under local anesthesia, and patients usually experience little to no discomfort. Once the device has served its purpose, itâ€™s removed easily. The site typically heals without complications.

Are TADs painful?"

label: general
post_content:
"Replanting dead teeth, also known as autotransplantation or tooth reimplantation, refers to the process of reinserting a tooth back into its original socket or transplanting it to another location in the mouth. However, the concept of replanting teeth from deceased individuals, such as dead soldiers, into living people is not a standard practice in modern dentistry.

Teeth from a deceased person would face significant challenges due to the degradation of tissues and the risk of infection. Furthermore, compatibility issues, immune responses, and ethical concerns would make this approach unviable. In modern dental care, lost or severely damaged teeth are typically replaced with dental implants, bridges, or dentures rather than attempting to transplant teeth from deceased individuals.

The use of human tissues for transplantation must follow strict protocols to ensure safety, and teeth transplantation from deceased individuals to living patients does not meet these standards.
@zackdfilms ğŸ«¥ğŸ«¥"

post_content:
"Do you know a mouth breather ? 

â€œMouth breatherâ€ refers to someone who habitually breathes through their mouth instead of their nose. This can happen for several reasons, like nasal congestion from allergies, a deviated septum, or enlarged tonsils. Long-term mouth breathing can lead to issues like dry mouth, bad breath, and even dental problems due to reduced saliva flow, which normally helps protect teeth. It can also impact facial development in children, sometimes leading to changes in jaw and tooth alignment.

If mouth breathing is a concern, it might be helpful to consult with a healthcare provider to address any underlying issues or discuss treatment options, such as nasal strips, orthodontics, or breathing exercises."

"ğŸ¦· ğŸª¥ ğŸ’« 

Over-brushing, or brushing your teeth too hard or for too long, can actually harm your oral health. Brushing aggressively can wear down the enamelâ€”the protective outer layer of your teethâ€”and lead to gum recession. Both of these issues increase sensitivity and make your teeth more susceptible to decay and other damage.

Hereâ€™s how to brush effectively without overdoing it:

	1.	Use a soft-bristled toothbrush: Hard bristles can be too abrasive for teeth and gums.
	2.	Brush for 2 minutes: Brushing twice a day for about 2 minutes each time is ideal. Donâ€™t brush for much longer.
	3.	Gentle pressure: Apply light pressure, as if youâ€™re massaging your teeth, not scrubbing them.
	4.	Use the right technique: Hold your brush at a 45-degree angle to your gum line, and use small circular motions rather than back-and-forth scrubbing.

Practicing gentle brushing habits can help protect your enamel and gums for the long run."

post_content:
"Yes, tongue rings can crack teeth. The hard metal or acrylic part of a tongue ring often comes into contact with the teeth, especially when chewing, talking, or even accidentally biting down on it. This impact can create small fractures or chips, and over time, it can lead to more significant damage, like cracking or breaking teeth entirely. Additionally, tongue rings can increase the risk of gum recession, enamel wear, and infections due to bacteria buildup.

If youâ€™re thinking about getting or already have a tongue ring, itâ€™s essential to be aware of these risks and take precautions, like using softer materials (if possible) and being mindful of the jewelryâ€™s position. Regular check-ups with a dentist can help catch any early signs of damage 

Who loves Tongue ğŸ‘… Rings ?"

label: general
post_content:
"Fluoride in toothpaste is generally safe and effective for dental health when used as directed. Fluoride helps strengthen enamel and prevent cavities, which is why itâ€™s a standard ingredient in most toothpastes. However, swallowing large amounts, especially over time, can be harmful, particularly to children whose smaller bodies are more sensitive to the substance. This is why young children should use only a small, pea-sized amount and be supervised while brushing.

In large quantities, fluoride can cause issues like fluorosis (white spots on teeth) or, rarely, more serious toxicity. But under normal use (brushing twice a day and spitting out the paste), fluoride toothpaste is safe for daily dental care.

Do you use fluoride toothpaste?"

post_content:
"The connection between oral health, particularly gum health, and heart disease is well-established. Inflammation and bacteria in the mouth can affect the heart, especially if gum disease (periodontitis) goes untreated. Hereâ€™s how theyâ€™re linked:

	1.	Bacteria and Inflammation: When you have gum disease, bacteria from your mouth can enter the bloodstream. This bacteria may cause inflammation, which can contribute to the formation of plaques in arteriesâ€”a process known as atherosclerosis. These plaques narrow arteries, potentially leading to cardiovascular issues.
	2.	Endothelial Damage: The inflammation from gum disease may damage the endothelium, which is the thin membrane lining the heart and blood vessels. Damage to this layer increases the risk of plaque formation, blood clots, and eventually, heart attacks or strokes.
	3.	Increased Risk for Heart Attack and Stroke: Studies have shown that people with periodontal disease are more likely to have heart disease. The relationship isnâ€™t entirely understood, but inflammation seems to play a significant role. This inflammation could potentially lead to a higher risk of heart attack or stroke.
	4.	Diabetes Connection: Since people with diabetes are at higher risk for both gum disease and heart disease, the connection between these diseases becomes even more critical. Proper oral care is particularly important for those with diabetes to reduce their cardiovascular risk.
	5.	Preventative Measures: Regular brushing, flossing, and dental check-ups can help reduce oral bacteria and inflammation. By keeping gum disease in check, you may also reduce your risk of heart disease."

post_content:
"This one is for all my sweaty gorlllsğŸ’˜

Probably the most normal yet unspoken about things at the gym??!!

I have had hyperhidrosis ever since I can remember and sweat has ALWAYS been my biggest insecurity- for SO many years I just wore black, simply because the sweat showed less!!

But after trying many medications to try and combat the excessive sweating - in the last few years I have decided to âœ¨own itâœ¨ - ESPECIALLY at the gym!! Wear whatever damn colours you WANT to wear, not what you feel like hides the sweat less!! 

Life is TOO SHORT to wear black every damn day just to cover a NATURAL way that our bodies cool themselves down!! ESPECIALLY when thereâ€™s so many beautiful colours to wearğŸ«¶ğŸ¼

So this is my challenge to you - WEAR A COLOURFUL SET. I promise you the world will not stop!!! A sweat patch at the gym is normal, we go to the gym to workout.. of course we will sweat!!! Even if you are like me and sweating 10x more then everyone else thereğŸ’œ

So hereâ€™s to anybody else that needs to hear it, my older self and the little voice inside my brain that sees the sweat patches I get and simply screams - it is okay. Itâ€™s just sweat. Itâ€™s normal - stop holding your life off and not wearing clothes in the fear of a little sweat markğŸ«¶ğŸ¼

"The power of your mindset!!!ğŸ§ ğŸ’—âœ¨

One thing I get asked a lot is how to start viewing life & yourself more positively and the answer is ALWAYS your mindset!!

For so long I believed that my body was the issue for my lack of confidence and that by changing that I would all of a sudden beam happiness and positivity (ps this did not work and actually resulted in me being the least positive and happy I had ever been)

By fixing your mindset and the way you speak to yourself, your brain automatically becomes a more positive place. The more you stop letting yourself speak badly to yourself, the less bad you will feel. We canâ€™t expect our life to be positive if our brain is not!!

Changing your mindset is a lot of work. Much like growing your muscles, you canâ€™t expect to see results overnight and it is something you have to continually keep working on!!â¤ï¸

"Just because your body changes throughout the day, doesnâ€™t mean your worth also changesğŸ’—

One thing I used to really struggle with was accepting myself when I was bloated!! I get EXTREME bloating (I think you can probably tellğŸ¤­) and can sometimes look even bigger than a woman 9 months pregnant - shoutout to being lactose AND gluten intolerant but still eating it 24/7ğŸ¤“

But throughout my journey of learning to love myself REGARDLESS of anything, this also meant learning to love and accept my bloated body, no matter how uncomfortable it made me feel in my skinğŸ«¶ğŸ½

A few years ago, I used to take a big jacket out with me so that when it inevitably happened, I could hide it. Fast forward to now, I couldnâ€™t care less!! Everyoneâ€™s body changes/ bloats, maybe not to the same extreme as mine, but it is normal for your body to fluctuate ğŸ«¶ğŸ»

Bloating is okay.
Enjoying yourself through food is okay.
Your belly being a bit too full is O K A Y!!

The next time you bloat, instead of covering it or feeling any kind of guilt, please remember - it happens to everyone. Nobody cares if you finish the day with a bigger belly than you started it!! Itâ€™s alllll in your head I promise youğŸ«¶ğŸ»

#bodypositive #bodypositivity #bloating #bloatingisnormal #bloat #bodypositivemovement #selflove #selfcare #bodyacceptance"

post_content:
"I have to give exercise a big thank you this pregnancy because I have been sooo moody. More than I was in my other two! 

Exercise has helped tamed and calmed this mama. ğŸ¤£ bless @jhalliday14 for putting up with me so graciously!

Personally, knowing the health benefits of exercise not only for me, but for baby as well, always gives me that little extra push to work through that initial tiredness. 

My workouts almost always ends up giving me the energy I so desperately need! Not only that, but itâ€™s such a mood stabilizer and booster.

BUT! That does not mean you should push yourself through exhaustion. Thereâ€™s so many barriers to exercise to begin with, pregnancy makes it that much harder.

So please have grace with yourself. Iâ€™m speaking for what personally has been helpful for me.

Rest is needed during first trimester. Itâ€™s important and necessary. ğŸ‘ğŸ¼ So if your body needs the rest, thatâ€™s what it needs.
Period.No guilt. Ever.

Here was a go to workout I did when I struggled moving! 
Air bike sprint for 30secs 
Some kind to core work 
Repeat 5-10x"

"Any leg day can be made to be a pregnancy safe workout and just because itâ€™s a â€œpregnancyâ€ workout doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s not a solid leg day for anyone ğŸ¥°

Voice overs on videos! 

Warmup: Iâ€™ve been really focusing on all the major muscles that attach into the pelvis so that as my pelvis begins to shift, itâ€™s supported! Itâ€™s a bit of â€œstabilizingâ€ work and minimizing changces of pelvic girdle pain.

Much of my workouts are staying the same as pre pregnancy but with shift in intensity and paying attention to pressure management in the core.

Now that Iâ€™m 15 weeks, I feel so much better energy wise and strength wise. Iâ€™m beginning to lift â€œheavierâ€ again. 

I take a more cautious approach for *myself* first trimester when estrogen & relaxin spike causing some connective tissue laxity and Iâ€™m prone to pelvic girdle pain. 

Now that things are settling, energy is coming back I feel ok pushing my intensity back up!

Come train with me! Link in bio for app. First trimester is about to launch on the app this week as well as the functional core education on playbook now! ğŸ¥°"

label: general
post_content:
"You are not broken during pregnancy but you are also not invincible. ğŸ‘ğŸ¼

Pressure seeks a path of least resistance. 

Your connective tissues and pelvic floor are more susceptible to pressure & potential injury due to ab separation from growing baby.

We know lifting is wonderful during pregnancy. ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¼

But we also know lifting increases pressure in our core canister, especially when coupled with breath holding techniques + load.

Because of this, minimizing extra stress to the abdominal wall & pelvic floor is a strategic choice in pregnancy training. 

So what does that mean? 

It means, what is safe for you is going to be determined by: 

ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½ your fitness level, core strength & experience 
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½ your connection to your deep core, pelvic floor, and breath
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½your ability to manage and disperse pressure in the core. (Thereâ€™s different breath strategies to do this. My core guide goes over it)

When to modify: 
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½ If the lift requires breath holding, valsalva, or straining, reduce weight. 
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½ If you see coning or belly shape changes due to pressure of the lift even after trying different breathing  strategies or alignment changes, reduce the weight. 
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½Any leaking or heaviness during OR after your session indicates it was too stressful on the system. 
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½Pain. Seems obvious but sometimes ppl gaslight themselves into thinking â€œitâ€™s way easier than I used to do, Iâ€™m fineâ€

This doesnâ€™t mean you cannot challenge yourself! There are so many ways to continue training and working hard without risking injury during or after to your body. Think longevity! Your body will thank you.

I have an in depth guide built with pelvic floor therapist that go into great detail on all of this!"

post_content:
"â€œWhatever you did pre-pregnancy, you can continueâ€â€¦Yes, but thereâ€™s more nuances to this recommendation ğŸ™ğŸ¼

As baby grows, your pelvic floor takes on an additional load and your abdominal muscles will split to create room for baby. This is a part of the process! You canâ€™t avoid it.

This makes your abdominal wall & pelvic floor more prone to pressure and potential injury.

Doing exercises that cause a lot of downward pressure and major coning is a repetitive stress to those structures. Especially if itâ€™s something done daily & with intensity.

Injuries like prolapse, incontinence, hernias and severe DR can become a much bigger issue to navigate and heal postpartum.

This doesnâ€™t mean we shouldnâ€™t move, or FEAR exercising. Quite the opposite.

It just gives us a better frame of strategic training during pregnancy to allow for the positive benefits of exercises WITH the easiest recovery postpartum given the circumstances weâ€™re in!

For more in depth education and guidance on all of this,  check out my core guide!

#fitpregnancy #pregnancyworkout #diastasisrecti"

post_content:
"Whatâ€™s something you were told you canâ€™t do with DR!? 

Healing DR can be frustrating. Thereâ€™s so many different â€œrulesâ€ out there & it can make it confusing on what you can & canâ€™t do.

Thereâ€™s appropriate exercises to do be doing at different stages in your DR healing journey.ğŸ‘ğŸ¼

The key in ALL stages, is progressive OVERLOAD. 

You have to challenge & load the connective tissues & muscles with enough stimulus, so a physiological response occurs in the tissues and muscles.

This is where most individuals find a stall in their progress.

Theyâ€™re afraid of â€œmaking it worseâ€ and in turn, halt progress because they arenâ€™t challenging the system enough, while avoiding important muscle groups like the â€œsix pack muscle.â€

Your deep core works with ALL the superficial core muscles. They are a TEAM. Lifting is a great way to challenge your core as a whole.

Yes, exercise selection & intentional movement within exercises is important. Yes, being aware if the exercise is too much or just right is also important. However, your body is pretty cool, resilient and will give you feedback on if itâ€™s too much. 

My Core guide will teach you all of this. Link in bio.

Lastly, TIME. Connective tissue takes a very long time to heal + strengthen. So keep chipping away. ğŸ«¶ğŸ½

For all things DR, rehab program and how to understand whatâ€™s going on in your deep core, how to move intentionally, my core guide is for you! Link in bio.

#diastasisrecti #diastasisrectiexercises #fitnessmotivation"

post_content:
"What is the craziest myth youâ€™ve been told during your pregnancy?

Although education is so much better than it used to be surrounding pregnancy training, there is still a lot of judgement, misinformed fears,Â Â and negative beliefs surrounding prenatal exercise: 

Here are some wild things Iâ€™ve been told:

Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Â Lifting my arms above my head will wrap the babyâ€™s cord around their neck.
Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Â Engaging my core was going to suffocate my baby.
Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Â Exercise would cause me to miscarry.
Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Â I was vain and selfish for continuing to exercise (as if I only exercise for aesthetics).

The list goes on ğŸ˜­

Luckily research is our friend, and it has without a doubt shown POSITIVE benefits for both mom and baby.ğŸ¤ 

Just to name a few:

Â Â Â Â âƒÂ ACOG no longer recognizes heart rate as an accurate measure of exertion. Now we go by Rate of Perceived Exertion
Â Â Â Â âƒÂ Exercise reduces the chance of gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, and hypertension.
Â Â Â Â âƒÂ Exercise reduces aches and pains: especially pelvic girdle and back pain.
Â Â Â Â âƒÂ Women who exercised tolerated labor better, not only themselves but their babies too.
Â Â Â Â âƒÂ Exercise increased viability of placenta, amniotic fluid and oxygen waste exchange (meaning exercise caused increased blood flow to your baby, not less).
Â Â Â Â âƒÂ Exercise has a positive effect on epigeneticâ€™s outcomes for baby.
Â Â Â Â âƒÂ Exercise can set the stage for an easier recovery postpartum.
Â Â Â Â âƒÂ Exercise aids in maternal mental health by reducing stress and aiding in better sleep.

Recourses: for all my research lovers, look in comments for full list

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233749975_Benefits_of_Exercise_During_Pregnancy
Am J Obstet Gynecol 2000;183:1484-1488.
J Pediatr 1996;129:856-863
Acta Obstet Gynecol Scand 2007;
86:547-552.

#pregnancy #pregnancytraining #pregnancyworkout #workoutroutine #safepregnancyexercise"

post_content: "So here's the story of Cliff & Chelsea ğŸ’˜ - Cliff became our mailman at the shop in 2021 during the pandemic. We started having small chit chat through our masks and over time I invited him in to see what we do as he was asking lots of questions about all these outgoing packages ğŸ“¦ ğŸ˜… I also let him to take off his mask so I could get peek! And ğŸ˜µğŸ˜We became more & more friendly but then he found out he was getting moved off our route. So on his last day as my mailman he asked me to go on a date with him and I said yes. Nearly 3 years later, on Tuesday in Cannon Beach Oregon he proposed with our families there, our StumP box and this ring that my patents made for us ğŸ’˜ğŸ’˜\nIt was a truly magical moment and I cannot wait to be Cliffs wife ğŸ’œ\nREALLY BIG SHOUT OUT TO USPS FOR THE HOOKUP ğŸ˜…ğŸ‘Œ"

label: general
post_content:
"I don't care where you begin the ride. I care that I helped you finish somewhere better â¤ï¸ğŸ´

"I'm not ready for a clinic"
"I'm not good enough to take a lesson from her"
"I'm still just learning the basics"
"I should be more prepared to go train"

Just start.
Start where you are. It is the only place you can begin, and best to do it with supportive, knowledgeable guidance so you can avoid frustrations and bad habits.
A good instructor will meet you where you and your horse are at, then build a strong foundation from there.

What do upper level horses and riders work on? The basics. It never goes away. Proper position. Good transitions. Lighter aids. More suppleness. Better balance. It's always the same, just with an increased standard for excellence. 

I'm so proud of this pair! They have come sooo far during their week of boot camp and now they both have a better understanding of the aids and basics, so they continue training with confidence ğŸ"

label: general
post_content: "Transitions!!!! We took a step aside from the fancy work to make the foundation work stronger (literally), so that he could carry himself lighter up front and more over his back. This horse already had easy, straight tempi changes, but a million halts and transitions he now stays more on his hindend, doesn't drift right, or lean into the hand ğŸ™Œ\n\nWe didn't only do walk canter Transitions. All the halt trot transitions got him quicker behind. Any downward transition got him rocked back more. No matter what I chose, they got him more responsive to the aids, agile and built strength to help him carry himself with more ease. He's a big guy!"

label: general
post_content:
"Which waterbear is cutest ğŸ˜ 1, 2 or 3?

Today I went waterbear aka tardigrade hunting. Am I was lucky enough to find 3 different species in the same sample of moss and lichen from a tree. However I canâ€™t decide which one of them is the cutest, can you help? ğŸ”¬

Tardigrades are some of the smallest animals on the planet. Most are around 500 microns in length. But the biggest can grow to around 1.5 millimeter.

These have been magnified over 200 times. But you should be able to see them with all microscopes. So you donâ€™t need a lot of fancy equipment to go â€œhuntingâ€ on your own.

The microscope is as always my @moticeurope BA310E ğŸ”¬

#science #biology #microscopy #underthemicroscope #animals #nature #life #microworld #microcosmos #ecology #microorganism #microscope #magnification #scienceandtechnology #microscopic #beautiful #protist #lichen #facts #motic #moticeurope #moticmicroscope #green #moss #waterbear #organism #tardigrade #colorful #cute"

label: general
post_content:
"The microworld can be a crowded place from time to time. When the environment/ecosystem changes, the new conditions might fit a single organisms needs so well that it will be able to reproduce with enormous speed creating a bloom of that particular organism. These are single celled organisms called spirostumum (with a single frontonia and a stentor as well) that exploded in numbers in my pond water sample when I left it for a few days.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

#science #biology #microscopy #underthemicroscope #cells #nature #life #microworld #microcosmos #ecology #microorganism #microscope #magnification #scienceandtechnology #microscopic #beautiful #protist #algae #facts #motic #moticeurope #moticmicroscope #crowded #pond #pondwater #organism #interresting #colorful"

label: general
post_content:
"Another crowded day in the microworld.

These green blobs are single celled organisms known as frontonia (f. vernalis). Their green color comes from their symbiotic relationship with algae living inside the cell. This provides the frontonia with oxygen from the algaes photosynthesis. At the same time the algae enjoy the waste products from the frontonias metabolism.

A lot of unicellular organisms, like this one, mainly feed on bacteria, but frontonia are capable of ingesting â€œenormousâ€ food particles (compared to their size). If you look closely, you are actually able to spot some of these large pieces of ingested matter inside some of the cells.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

#science #biology #microscopy #underthemicroscope #cells #nature #life #microworld #microcosmos #ecology #microorganism #microscope #magnification #scienceandtechnology #microscopic #beautiful #protist #algae #facts #motic #moticeurope #moticmicroscope #crowded #pond #pondwater #organism #interresting #colorful"

label: general
post_content:
"Something as simple as bubbles in soapy water can look magical when viewed through a microscope.
The tiny bubbles have been magnified more than 100 times and are illuminated with something called polarized light to introduce color to the images.

The microscope is as always my amazing @moticeurope BA310E ğŸ”¬ and the camera is my just as wonderful @nikoneurope z50 ğŸ“¸ 

#science #biology #microscopy #microscope #microworld #beautiful #colorful #bubbles #magical #scienceandtechnology #art #photography #moticmicroscope #nikonz50 #createyourlight"

label: general
post_content:
"Amoebas are unicellular shapeshifters. They move around by extending their cell membrane in the desired way of movement. These cellular projections are then filled with the cell contents, which create a sort of rolling movement like a microscopic conveyer belt, or a tiny tank if you prefer that analogy.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

#science #biology #microscopy #underthemicroscope #cells #nature #life #microworld #microcosmos #ecology #microorganism #microscope #magnification #scienceandtechnology #microscopic #beautiful #protist #algae #facts #motic #moticeurope #moticmicroscope #amoeba #pond #pondwater #organism #interresting #colorful"

label: general
post_content:
"This little slow-stepper is a tardigrade aka waterbear. These animals are some of the smallest and toughest on the planet. Most measure around 500 microns like this one. Tardigrades are able to enter an inactive state where they are almost impossible to kill. They can endure enormous pressure, high radiation, pure vacuum, and temperatures lower than -200 C and above 100 C.
The animal in the video is actually from a moss sample I took several months ago and have kept in my freezer since. When I added water to the sample, the little fella came â€œback to lifeâ€ after a couple of minutes. And started waddling around like nothing had happened.

The microscope used is as always my fantastic @moticeurope BA310E ğŸ”¬

#science #biology #microscopy #microscope #ecology #scienceandtechnology #nature #animals #microscopic #tardigrade #waterbear #cuteanimals #underthemicroscope #microworld"

label: general
post_content: "Rotifers are micro animals more commonly known as wheel animals. This is due to the presence of tiny beating hair like projections on their heads which kind of look like turning wheels. The animals use these projections called cilia to feed. Here they are stuffing themselves with a feast of bacteria in the water.\nThe microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.\n#science #biology #microscopy #underthemicroscope #cells #nature #life #microworld #microcosmos #ecology #microorganism #microscope #magnification #scienceandtechnology #microscopic #beautiful #rotifer #algae #facts #motic #moticeurope #moticmicroscope #pond #pondwater #organism #interresting #colorful #bacteria"

label: general
post_content:
"This golden beauty is a single colony of an alga called synura. The colony is only about 25 microns in size, which is roughly a quarter of the thickness of a single human hair. Each cell is equipped with two tiny beating hair-like projections called flagella which the colony use to move to find the optimal places for photosynthesis.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

#science #biology #microscopy #underthemicroscope #cells #nature #life #microworld #microcosmos #ecology #microorganism #microscope #magnification #scienceandtechnology #microscopic #beautiful #synura #algae #facts #motic #moticeurope #moticmicroscope #pond #pondwater #organism #interresting #colorful #golden"

"Inspired by one of @jam_and_germs latest videos I got my hands on a leaf of the water plant elodea.
This plant is a brilliant specimen for science classes to show both chloroplasts, plant cells, cytoplasmic steaming and more!
Every time I look at this plant in a microscope I am blown away by the enormous complexity, elegance and beauty nature has to offer!

The clip is at 1900% speed

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"In this clip my blood cells are sealing the thin gap between the microscope slide and coverslipğŸ©¸

When we puncture our skin and start to bleed, a complicated process known as coagulation takes place to stop the bleeding. The goal of coagulation is to form a clot that seals the hole in the blood vessel. Such a clot is made up of platelets, fibrin and red blood cells . When these interact the blood changes from a liquid to a gel stateğŸ©¸

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

#science #biology #microscopy #underthemicroscope #cells #nature #life #microworld #microcosmos #ecology #microorganism #microscope #magnification #scienceandtechnology #microscopic #beautiful #blood #nurse #facts #motic #moticeurope #moticmicroscope #medicine #redbloodcells #organism #interresting #colorful #red"

label: general
post_content:
"These are some of my favorite microscopy clips of all time!
Clip 1: Different single celled organisms I found in a sample from a small forrest pond. The two large ones are called stentors. Inside them you can see some of the different things they have ingested.
Clip 2: One of the smallest animals on the planet called a rotifer in a sea of algae called haematococcus. This animal is also known as a wheel animalcule due to the presence of tiny beating hair like projections resembling turning wheels. This sample was from a bucket at a construction site.
Clip 3: The purple structure in the center is a colony of purple sulfur bacteria. Orbiting the colony are different single celled organisms.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"Letâ€™s dive into a forest pond together.
A couple of days ago, I collected my first sample in several months. So, I dusted off my trusty microscope and camera to see if I could find some micro-creatures to show you. And the sample did not disappoint! The diversity and colors in the water were incredible. I also managed to find a rare microorganism I have found in this forest pond before called Spirostomum semivirescens (itâ€™s the long slender green one). This time I actually found a lot of them!
All the clips in the video are from two tiny drops of water from the sample, and there are a lot more clips and organisms I was unable to fit into the short video. Hopefully I will be able to include them in some other posts soon.

I hope you enjoy the video.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"A couple of days ago I took a water sample from a small forest pond. That sample have been sitting, undisturbed, on my desk in the same sample jar ever since.  That means that the oxygen concentration is very low in the water by now. But no worries. The organisms you see in this video are fully adapted to handle these conditions. A lot of the organisms are green, which mean they have a symbiotic relationship with algae living inside them. This allows the organisms to produce their own oxygen. A bit like a permanent internal scuba tank. If that isnâ€™t brilliant, I donâ€™t know what is!

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"This cute little thing is a tardigrade, one of the smallest animals on the planet! Most tardigrades measure around 500 microns in size. Thatâ€™s about 5 times the thickness of a single human hair. However, the smallest can be 10 times smaller than that (around 50 microns), and the largest can be over 1 mm in length. But donâ€™t let their size fool you. Tardigrades are possibly the toughest animal on earth. They are capable of surviving total desiccation, enormous amounts of pressure and radiation, freezing and boiling temperatures, and of course the vacuum of space. To test some of this, the tardigrade in the video have been desiccated and store in my freezer at -18 degrees centigrade for several months. Yesterday I took the sample out of the freezer, added a bit of water, and 10 minutes later this happy little fellow was ready to party like nothing happened.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"This is the blue whale of the microworld. It is called stentor coeruleus and it is one of the biggest single celled organisms on the planet. These cells are so big that they are larger than some animals, and can often be seen with the unaided eye. Stentors feed and move using tiny beating hairlike projections called cilia, which can be seen in the front of the cell. Inside the cell is a structure that resembles a pearl necklace. This is the nucleus containing the cells DNA ğŸ§¬.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"One of my favorite places to take samples from are small garden bird baths. They are always filled with so many microorganisms. This one had A LOT of rotifers, also known as wheel animals. Rotifers are some of the smallest animals on the planet. Most measure less than half a millimeter, and some are 10 times smaller than that. The ones in the video are fairly large though, but still under a millimeter in length. These ones have a beautiful deep orange color due to the food they eat. This bird bath also contained a large amount of a specific algae called haematococcus which produces a red pigment called astaxanthin. When the rotifers feed on the algae. Their bellies become full of this red pigment. Giving the animals their sticking color.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"Daphnias are tiny crustaceans measuring only about 1-5 millimeters in length. Most of these animals have been dormant in resting eggs all winter. But now with temperatures rising and conditions improving, the eggs hatch and the daphnias start multiplying rapidly.
Daphnias can be found I many freshwater habitats like ponds, lakes and streams. Here they feed on micro algae which they filter out of the water with their moving front appendages.
These animals are illuminated with polarized light which make their muscle fibers glow in beautiful colors.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"These squiggly little worms are nematodes, also known as roundworms. They are one of the most abundant, if not the most abundant animals on the planet.
Most roundworms are harmless to humans and serves to help degrade dead plant material and are play an important part in healthy soil.
However, not all are helpful. Some are parasitic and can infect humans. Most common is the infection called ascariasis with about 1 BILLION infected humans right now!

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"Symbiosis is a term used to describe two species living in a mutually beneficial relationship. Which means that both species gets something out of the arrangement.
Here you see some different species of green single celled organisms. All are green because of the presence of endosymbiotic algae living inside the cells. This provides oxygen for the cells and as a thank you, the algae get to snack on the waste products from the cell. Two species living together in perfect harmony, each one making the other stronger.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

"These cute little fellas are marine bristle worms. Some of the most abundant animals on the sea floor. In fact there are around 1000-3000 of them in each square meter of the top layer of sand. So the next time you are at the beach and you feel something tingling your toes, these might be at play. Most are microscopic or at least very tiny. But they can reach a size of up to 50 centimeters. And at that size they can give a fairly painful bite with their powerful jaws.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

post_content:
"Science fiction or real? This worm is commonly known as a black worm, or lumbriculus variegatus if you want to be fancy about it. The worm lives in freshwater habitats around the world, and this specific one came from a pond water sample I took yesterday. Where I found it in the sediment in the bottom of my sample. Here they aid in the breakdown of organic materials.
Right now there is not much â€˜blackâ€™ about this worm. This is because I have illuminated it with polarized light which makes the muscle layers change color depending on the orientation in the light. But if the colors arenâ€™t sci-fi enough for you maybe this is. The worm reproduces most of the time by being separated in two pieces. Each piece will then regrow, one grows a new head and the other a new tail.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"Tardigrades, also known as water bears, are microscopic creatures known for their incredible ability to survive in extreme environments. These tiny animals, about 0.5 mm long, can endure temperatures as low as -328Â°F (-200Â°C) and as high as 300Â°F (150Â°C). They can even survive the vacuum of space and high levels of radiation! Tardigrades live in diverse habitats, from oceans and lakes to damp moss and soil.

This one is grazing on a piece of plant debris from a moss sample. But their diet also includes other plant cells, algae, and small invertebrates. When conditions become harsh, they enter a state called cryptobiosis, where they lose almost all water and can stay dormant for years, reviving when their surroundings improve.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E

label: general
post_content:
"Microscopic Anatomy and Physiology Lessons ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ«
I work at a nursing school in Denmark ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡° where I teach anatomy and physiology to nursing students. So letâ€™s have a little lesson in the anatomy and physiology of the digestive tract. This transparent worm allows us to observe peristaltic movements in the digestive tract. These rhythmic contractions are responsible for moving the contents of the digestive system from one end to the other while mixing them with digestive juices, which aids digestion and the absorption of nutrients. When peristaltic movements slow down, become less frequent, or weaken, constipation can occur. Factors that can increase peristalsis include regular exercise, a fiber-rich diet, and adequate fluid intake, all of which help prevent or alleviate constipation.

The microscope used here is as always, my wonderful and trusty @moticeurope BA310E with my @nikoneurope Z50 camera.

label: general
post_content:
"Most of what you see in the video are tiny pellets of starch from the ginger. The spirulina is the spiral shape green structures. And no, this post is not sponsored by 7-eleven.

Spirulina is a nutrient-rich Cyanobacteria that has been consumed for centuries due to its health-promoting properties. Packed with protein, vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, spirulina is often considered a superfood. It contains essential nutrients like B vitamins, iron, magnesium, and omega-3 fatty acids, making it a popular dietary supplement.

The health benefits of spirulina include boosting immune function, reducing inflammation, and supporting heart health by lowering cholesterol and blood pressure. Its high antioxidant content helps combat oxidative stress, while its protein and amino acid profile make it an excellent option for muscle repair and overall energy. Spirulina may also aid in detoxification by binding to heavy metals and promoting liver health.

The microscope used is as always my fantastic @moticeurope BA310E and the camera used is a @nikoneurope Z50

"Lately I have been reflecting on this past year. I feel like we work so hard all year, and then as soon as the holidays are over we are already setting New Yearâ€™s resolutions to get back to work. 

But I think we are meant to rest for much longer than just the holidays. Now is the time to give our bodies deep rest and to really reset our body, mind, and spirit. 

This year my new years intention is to continue to be cozy inside, reading next to the fire, drinking lots of warm tea and soup, continue to eat lots of cookies, and  get ready for this next spring season. I already know so much will be happening here on the farm in the spring and summer, so before then I plan on continuing my season of rest â¤ï¸"
